children: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for unexplained anemia.
A Prussian blueâ€“stained bone marrow aspiration is
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is sideroblastic anemia. This bone marrow examination is remarkable for the presence of

. These cells are characterized by small, blue-staining, iron-containing granules arranged in a ring around the nucleus of erythroid precursors. Ringed sideroblasts are associated with a variety of disorders that have ineffective erythropoiesis and hyperferremia in common. Sideroblastic anemia may be congenital or acquired. Acquired forms may be associated with the myelodysplastic syndrome; be idiopathic; or occur in the context of alcohol use disorder, copper deficiency, lead toxicity, or the use of certain drugs (such as linezolid and isoniazid).

objective.__html: Diagnose ringed sideroblasts and associated sideroblastic anemia.
